course_title: Honours Research Project in Veterinary Technology

learning_outcomes.description: Have the ability to perform self-directed, original and independent research
Display skills in time management, problem solving and organisation
Have a sound understanding of the selected field of research and highlight areas which require further research and innovation
Have the ability to critically evaluate other studies in this area of research as well as critically evaluate and highlight any problems in this study
Display skills in experimental design and appropriate statistical analysis and able to draw valid conclusions from the analysis
Convey and communicate ideas in a number of different ways (verbal and written)
Be able to work as part of a functioning laboratory and part of a university system and be able to work effectively with others as part of a cohesive research team

assessments.due_date: The Learning Contract is to be submitted at the time of the Project Proposal Seminar
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a Learning Contract at the time of the Project Proposal Seminar. A Learning Contract template can be obtained from the Course Blackboard site.

The Learning Contract is a Pass/Fail assessment item. This document will be a collaboration between the supervisor(s) and the student within four weeks of commencing study.

The purpose of this document is to ensure, where possible, that the following aspects are addressed before the Census Date:

  • The project has been considered;
  • The supervisor(s)/student responsibilities and study plan have been discussed and agreed upon;
  • Research integrity, budgets, compliance with UQ policies, compliance with external regulatory bodies and funding opportunities have been discussed and understood; 
  • Due diligence is completed; this has been included to ensure the student has every opportunity to succeed in this program.


This is a Pass/Fail item, based on submission of the completed form. Students who are unable to submit the form by the due date will be recommended to withdraw from the program before the census date.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
9/03/2026 - 27/03/2026

A time, date and location will be organised by mutual agreement between student, supervisor(s) and course coordinator for the project proposal seminar presentation within the assessment period.
assessments.task_description:
This Project Proposal Seminar occurs early in the candidature and is designed to allow the student to communicate their proposed research to their peers. It will include an overview of the area of research, a research question or hypothesis, and an outline of the approach that will be used to address this.

The research plan and proposal seminar will be assessed by the Honours Coordinator, and an additional examiner with feedback provided to the student.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.due_date:
2/11/2026 - 20/11/2026

A mutually agreeable date will be organised between the student, supervisor(s) and course coordinator for the presentation of the Honours Seminar.
assessments.task_description:
20-25 min oral presentation of the student's Honours research project (in-person, Gatton campus)

Seminars should follow the structure of a standard 30min research seminar, with a 20-25min presentation followed by questions from the panel for 5-10 minutes.

Students should seek detailed guidance from their supervisor (s) for the development and review of their seminar.

Students must prepare a seminar abstract suitable for advertising the seminar throughout SVS, have this reviewed by their advisors, and provide the abstract to the course coordinator 2 weeks before their agreed presentation date.

See the SVS BVetTech Honours handbook on the course Blackboard site for further information. A template for the seminar is also available on Blackboard.

This honours seminar is worth 25% of the assessment, and it will be assessed by the thesis examiners or others as appointed by the course coordinator.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This will be an in-person presentation on the Gatton Campus, with an abstract due to the course coordinator TWO (2) weeks before the agreed presentation date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
30/10/2026 2:00 pm

Thesis will be submitted by 2pm of the final day of the second semester of study.
assessments.task_description:
Students will submit a final Honours thesis. The thesis will include an abstract, introduction (detailing previous work and the aims and hypotheses of the current study), methodology, results, discussion (including conclusions) and references. Details on the format and content requirements of the honours thesis are available on the course Blackboard and in the SVS BVetTech honours handbook.

The final thesis will be examined by two examiners – normally, this will be conducted by two internal examiners or one internal examiner and one external to the School of Veterinary Science (SVS). The percentage mark awarded will be the average of the two examiners' marks. Thesis marks will be subject to a moderation process conducted by the course coordinator or a discipline expert nominated by the course coordinator if they differ by 10% or more. A third examiner will be used and the final thesis mark an average of the three marks.

A mark of no less than 50% in the honours thesis is required to pass the course.

An overall mark of no less than 50% is required to pass the course.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: When you are satisfied that you can make no further improvements in the quality of your thesis, then it is time to submit your thesis and this will be through the TURNITIN system and a link will be provided near to the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
30/10/2026 2:00 pm

Supervisor Evaluation will be submitted by the Primary Supervisor by the thesis due date.
assessments.task_description:
Supervisor(s) will grade students according to their engagement in the research project. This document should be reviewed collaboratively by the supervisor and student at the start of candidature, so both parties understand what will be assessed during the course.

The supervisor(s) mark is an objective assessment of the overall quality of the student in terms of their scholarship, practical competence and professional approach to research.

The supervisor evaluation form is available on Blackboard. The principal supervisor must send the completed evaluations to the course coordinator via email by the due date. Where a student has multiple supervisors who do not agree on a single evaluation, supervisors may submit their evaluations separately to the course coordinator. An average mark from all advisory inputs will be used for grading.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Supervisor Evaluation will be submitted by the Primary Supervisor
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
